sections.title:
A new approach to investigation of Maxwell equations in spherical
coordinates
sections.abstract:
In this article general solution to the Maxwell equations
in spherical coordinates is constructed. The method of expansion of
unknown functions into series of spherical harmonics is used. It is
shown that the exterior boundary value problems for the Maxwell
equations have the unique oriented solutions, and the interior
boundary value problems have non-trivial solutions in the case of
resonance. Necessary and sufficient solvability conditions of
over-determined boundary value problems for the Maxwell equations
are found.
sections.author: N.\,B.\,Pleshchinskii , D.\,N.\,Tumakov
sections.shorttit: A new approach to investigation of Maxwell
sections.keywords:
Maxwell set of equations, spherical coordinates,
over-determined boundary value problem
sections.introduction:
Boundary value problems for the Maxwell equations in spherical
coordinates arise in various areas of physics. The light phenomena
in colloidal solutions were investigated in the classical work of
Mie (1908). Today the Mie theory is used very widely \cite{wri}. The
problem of electromagnetic wave diffraction by a sphere plays a
significant role in the theory of wave propagation along the surface
of the Earth \cite{nik}. Nowadays, great interest to the problems of
spherical antenna synthesis \cite{pon} and to the electromagnetic
field scattering problems by the biological objects \cite{sel} is
observed.

The problem of diffraction of the electromagnetic wave by the sphere
is a key problem of electrodynamics \cite{hmw}. The analytical
solution of this problem in the form of series of spherical
harmonics can be found in the book \cite{str}. The particular
solutions of the Maxwell equations can be obtained by the method of
separation of variables after transition to equations for the Debye
potentials or for the Hertz vectors \cite{hmw}, \cite{ang}. The case
of anisotropic media was investigated also in \cite{nov},
\cite{gen}.

\vskip2mm In this work the general representation of the electromagnetic
field in spherical coordinates is directly constructed on the basis of
analysis of the Maxwell set of equations.

The method of Fourier transform by tangential variables is the main
method for investigation on partial differential equations in the
half-spaces in Cartesian coordinates. This method reduces the set of
partial differential equations with constant coefficients to a simpler
set of ordinary differential equations for unknown functions.

We propose to extend this idea to the case of Maxwell equations
set for the complex amplitudes of the harmonic electromagnetic field
in the homogeneous isotropic medium
%\begin{equation}\label{e1}
\mbox{rot}\;\mathbf{H}=i\omega\varepsilon_0\varepsilon\,\mathbf{E},\quad
\mbox{rot}\;\mathbf{E}=-i\omega\mu_0\mu\,\mathbf{H}
\end{equation}%
in the spherical coordinates $(r,\theta,\alpha)$(the time
dependence has the form $\exp(i\omega t)\;$).

Suppose that the spherical surface $r=R$ splits the space
into two parts: the interior of the sphere $r<R$ and the exterior of
the sphere $r>R$. We consider the latitude $\theta$ and the
longitude $\alpha$ as the tangential variables.

The solutions to the set of equations for the expansion coefficients
of the field in the Fourier series are found in the form of two addends.
The first addends represent series of associated Legendre functions. The second
addends are chosen such that the equations to determine coefficients
in the first addends can be obtained in the simplest form.

We determine special classes of solutions to the Maxwell set: positively
and negatively oriented solutions, non-oriented solutions and
solutions bounded in the center of the sphere. Just as expected,
the exterior boundary value problems for the Maxwell set
have the unique oriented solutions, and the interior boundary value
problems have non-trivial solutions in the case of resonance. The
over-determined boundary value problems for the Maxwell set of
equations are also considered. Necessary and sufficient conditions of
solvability of these problems for equations are found in the form of connections
between traces on the sphere of the tangential components of oriented solutions
to the set of equations for Fourier coefficients of the field.

The method of over-determined boundary value problem (MODP) was
proposed to solve the problem of electro\-magnetic wave diffraction by
the metallic screens in the case of Cartesian coordinates in
\cite{ple5}; MODP for the case of other orthogonal coordinates was used in
\cite{ple1}, \cite{ple2}. The problems of electromagnetic wave diffraction
by thin conducting screens were discussed in papers \cite{ple5}, \cite{tum1}.
Analysis of electromagnetic wave propagation through a layer with graded-index
distribution of refractive index was given in \cite{ple6}. The case of
non-orthogonal coordinates was considered in the paper \cite{tum2}.
MODP was used to investigate elastic wave diffraction problem in \cite{ple4}.
The one-dimensional problem of diffraction by an elastic gradient layer
was solved by MODP in \cite{tum3}. The problems of plane diffraction by isotropic
and transversely isotropic layers were investigated in \cite{tum4} and \cite{tum5}.

We plan to use MODP for investigating some problems of electro\-magnetic wave
diffraction by spherical thin conducting screens in the near future.
The parallel algorithm for solving the problems of diffraction by a spherical screen
was discussed in \cite{ple3}.
main_part:
The set of equations (\ref{e1}) can be written down in the coordinate form
%%\begin{equation*}%\label{e2}%\begin{split}$$
\frac1{r\sin\theta}\,\frac{\partial(\sin\theta\cdot
H_\alpha)}{\partial\theta} -\frac1{r\sin\theta}\,\frac{\partial
H_\theta}{\partial\alpha}=i\omega\varepsilon_0\varepsilon\,E_r,\\
$$$$
\frac1{r\sin\theta}\,\frac{\partial(\sin\theta\cdot
E_\alpha)}{\partial\theta}
-\frac1{r\sin\theta}\,\frac{\partial E_\theta}{\partial\alpha}=-i\omega\mu_0\mu\,H_r,\\
$$$$
\frac1{r\sin\theta}\,\frac{\partial H_r}{\partial\alpha}-\frac1r\,
\frac{\partial(r\,H_\alpha)}{\partial r}
=i\omega\varepsilon_0\varepsilon\,E_\theta,\quad
\frac1{r\sin\theta}\,\frac{\partial E_r}{\partial\alpha}-\frac1r\,
\frac{\partial(r\,E_\alpha)}{\partial r}
=-i\omega\mu_0\mu\,H_\theta,\\
$$$$
\frac1r\,\frac{\partial(r\,H_\theta)}{\partial r}-\frac1r\,
\frac{\partial
H_r}{\partial\theta}=i\omega\varepsilon_0\varepsilon\,E_\alpha,\quad
\frac1r\,\frac{\partial(r\,E_\theta)}{\partial r}-\frac1r\,
\frac{\partial E_r}{\partial\theta}=-i\omega\mu_0\mu\,H_\alpha.
$$%\end{split}%\end{equation*}%
It is necessary to use the expansions in generalized Fourier series
of the functions $E_r$, $E_\theta$, $E_\alpha$, $H_r$, $H_\theta$,
$H_\alpha$ instead of the Fourier transforms. The spherical
functions
$
S_{n,m}(\theta,\alpha)=P^{(m)}_n(\cos\theta)\,e^{im\alpha},\quad
m=0,\pm 1,\dots,\quad n=|m|,|m|+1,\dots,
$
where $P^{(m)}_n(\cdot)$ are the associated Legendre functions.
These functions form complete orthogonal set of functions on the sphere.

Denote
$
\varphi_n(\theta)=P^{(m)}_n(\cos\theta),\quad n=|m|,|m|+1,\dots
$
Here and further we will not write down the number $m$ for the briefness
of the formulas. It is known that the associate Legendre functions are the
solutions of ordinary differential equation
%\begin{equation}\label{e3}
\frac{d}{d\theta}(\sin\theta\cdot\varphi'_n(\theta))
=\Bigl[\frac{m^2}{\sin\theta}-n(n+1)\sin\theta\Bigr]\,\varphi_n(\theta).
\end{equation}%
These functions are orthogonal over segment $[0,\pi]$ with the
weight $\sin\theta$.

An arbitrary function on the sphere can be expanded into absolutely
regular series of the spherical functions, if it has continuous
second derivatives. But it is possible to realize this expansion in
two stages: firstly to expand to series in variable $\alpha$, and
secondly to expand in series in variable $\theta$.

The Fourier coefficients of the functions
$E_r,\,E_\theta,\,E_\alpha,\,H_r,\,H_\theta,H_\alpha$ in series of
the form
$
%\begin{equation*}%\label{e4}
A(r,\theta,\alpha)=\sum_{m=-\infty}^{+\infty}A_m(r,\theta)e^{im\alpha},
%\end{equation*}
$
are solutions of the set of equations
%\begin{equation}\label{e5}
\begin{split}
\frac{\partial(\sin\theta\cdot H_\alpha)}{\partial\theta}
-im\,H_\theta=i\omega\varepsilon_0\varepsilon\,r\sin\theta\cdot E_r,\\
\frac{\partial(\sin\theta\cdot E_\alpha)}{\partial\theta}
-im\,E_\theta=-i\omega\mu_0\mu\,r\sin\theta\cdot H_r,\\
i m\,H_r-\sin\theta\,\frac{\partial(r\,H_\alpha)}{\partial r}
=i\omega\varepsilon_0\varepsilon\,r\sin\theta\cdot E_\theta,\\
i m\,E_r-\sin\theta\,\frac{\partial(r\,E_\alpha)}{\partial r}
=-i\omega\mu_0\mu\,r\sin\theta\cdot H_\theta,\\
\frac{\partial(r\,H_\theta)}{\partial r}
-\frac{\partial H_r}{\partial\theta}=i\omega\varepsilon_0\varepsilon\,r\,E_\alpha,\quad
\frac{\partial(r\,E_\theta)}{\partial r}
-\frac{\partial E_r}{\partial\theta}=-i\omega\mu_0\mu\,r\,H_\alpha
\end{split}
\end{equation}%(we remind that the number $m$ is omitted).

Now we will prove the following auxiliary statement.

\vskip2mm
\textbf{Lemma.}\enskip{\it
If
$$
\sum_{n=|m|}^{+\infty}A_n\,\varphi_n(\theta)
+\frac1{p}\sum_{n=|m|}^{+\infty}B_n\,\sin\theta\cdot\varphi'_n(\theta)=f(\theta),\quad
\frac1{q}\sum_{n=|m|}^{+\infty}A_n\,\sin\theta\cdot\varphi'_n(\theta)
+\sum_{n=|m|}^{+\infty}B_n\,\varphi_n(\theta)=g(\theta),
$$
for all $\theta\in[0,\pi]$ and $p\,q=m^2\ne0$, then
$$
A_k=F_{k,m}\; q\int\limits_0^{\pi}\Bigl[
\frac{p}{\sin\theta}\,f(\theta)-g'(\theta)\Bigr]\,\varphi_k(\theta)\;d\theta,\quad
B_k=F_{k,m}\; p\int\limits_0^{\pi}\Bigl[
\frac{q}{\sin\theta}\,g(\theta)-f'(\theta)\Bigr]\,\varphi_k(\theta)\;d\theta,
$$
where $F_{k,m}=\displaystyle\frac{(2k+1)}{2k(k+1)}\,\frac{(k-m)!}{(k+m)!}.$}\vskip2mm
\emph{Proof}.
Let us differentiate the second equality. Using formula (\ref{e3}) we can
rewrite it in the form
$$
\frac1{q}\sum_{n=|m|}^{+\infty}A_n\,\Bigl[\frac{m^2}{\sin\theta}-n(n+1)\sin\theta\Bigr]
\,\varphi_n(\theta)+\sum_{n=|m|}^{+\infty}B_n\,\varphi'_n(\theta)=g'(\theta).
$$
Let us multiply the first equality by $p/\sin\theta$ and then
subtract it from the second one. If $p\,q=m^2$ then
$$
\sum_{n=|m|}^{+\infty}A_n\,n(n+1)\sin\theta\,\varphi_n(\theta)
=q\,\Bigl[\frac{p}{\sin\theta}\,f(\theta)-g'(\theta)\Bigr].
$$
We multiply this equality by $\varphi_k(\theta)$ and integrate from
$0$ to $\pi$. The functions $\varphi_n(\theta)$ are orthogonal on the segment $[0,\pi]$ and
$$
\int\limits_0^{\pi}\varphi^2_k(\theta)\sin\theta\;d\theta=\frac2{2k+1}\,\frac{(k+m)!}{(k-m)!}.
$$
By this the representations of the coefficients $A_k$ are obtained.
Other coefficients $B_k$ can be found by a similar way.
\enskip$\bullet$

This case is more difficult to investigate. If we substitute the expansions of the
unknown functions by functions $\varphi_n(\theta)$ into equations
(\ref{e5}), then series appear with the factors $\varphi_n(\theta)$,
$\sin\theta\cdot\varphi_n(\theta)$, $\varphi'_n(\theta)$,
$\sin\theta\cdot\varphi'_n(\theta)$.

We propose to find the solutions to the set of equations (\ref{e5})
in the form
%$$
E_r(r,\theta)=\frac1{im}\sum_{n=|m|}^{+\infty}E_{r,n}(r)\,\varphi_n(\theta), \quad
H_r(r,\theta)=\frac1{im}\sum_{n=|m|}^{+\infty}H_{r,n}(r)\,\varphi_n(\theta), \\
$$$$
E_\theta(r,\theta)=-\frac{i\omega\mu_0\mu}{\sin\theta}\sum_{n=|m|}^{+\infty}
E_{\theta,n}(r)\,\varphi_n(\theta)
+\frac1{im}\sum_{n=|m|}^{+\infty}E^{add}_{\theta,n}(r)\,\varphi'_n(\theta),
$$$$
E_\alpha(r,\theta)=\frac{\omega\mu_0\mu}{m}\sum_{n=|m|}^{+\infty}
E^{add}_{\alpha,n}(r)\,\varphi'_n(\theta)
+\frac1{\sin\theta}\sum_{n=|m|}^{+\infty}E_{\alpha,n}(r)\,\varphi_n(\theta),
$$$$
H_\theta(r,\theta)=\frac1{im}\sum_{n=|m|}^{+\infty}H^{add}_{\theta,n}(r)\,\varphi'_n(\theta)
+\frac{i\omega\varepsilon_0\varepsilon}{\sin\theta}\sum_{n=|m|}^{+\infty}H_{\theta,n}(r)\,\varphi_n(\theta),
$$\begin{equation}\label{e10}
\begin{split}
H_\alpha(r,\theta)=\frac1{\sin\theta}\sum_{n=|m|}^{+\infty}H_{\alpha,n}(r)\,\varphi_n(\theta)
-\frac{\omega\varepsilon_0\varepsilon}{m}\sum_{n=|m|}^{+\infty}H^{add}_{\alpha,n}(r)\,\varphi'_n(\theta).
\end{split}
\end{equation}%
We substitute these representations into equations (\ref{e5}) and obtain
%\begin{multline}\label{e11}
\sum_{n=|m|}^{+\infty}\bigl[H_{\alpha,n}(r)-H^{add}_{\theta,n}(r)\bigr]\,\varphi'_n(\theta)
-\omega\varepsilon_0\varepsilon\,m\sum_{n=|m|}^{+\infty}\bigl[H^{add}_{\alpha,n}(r)-H_{\theta,n}(r)\bigr]\,
\frac{\varphi_n(\theta)}{\sin\theta}\\
+\frac{\omega\varepsilon_0\varepsilon}{m}\sum_{n=|m|}^{+\infty}
\bigl[n(n+1)\,H^{add}_{\alpha,n}(r)-r\,E_{r,n}(r)\bigr]\,\sin\theta\cdot\varphi_n(\theta)
=0,
\end{multline}\begin{multline}\label{e12}
\omega\mu_0\mu\,m\sum_{n=|m|}^{+\infty}\bigl[E^{add}_{\alpha,n}(r)-E_{\theta,n}(r)\bigr]\,
\frac{\varphi_n(\theta)}{\sin\theta}
+\sum_{n=|m|}^{+\infty}\bigl[E_{\alpha,n}(r)-E^{add}_{\theta,n}(r)\bigr]\,\varphi'_n(\theta)\\
-\frac{\omega\mu_0\mu}{m}\sum_{n=|m|}^{+\infty}
\bigl[n(n+1)\,E^{add}_{\alpha,n}(r)-r\,H_{r,n}(r)\bigr]\,\sin\theta\cdot\varphi_n(\theta)
=0.
\end{multline}%
Therefore it is convenient to choose
$H^{add}_{\theta,n}(r)=H_{\alpha,n}(r)$, $\;H^{add}_{\alpha,n}(r)=H_{\theta,n}(r)$,
$\;E^{add}_{\alpha,n}(r)=E_{\theta,n}(r)$, $\;E^{add}_{\theta,n}(r)=E_{\alpha,n}(r)$.

\vskip2mm
\textbf{Theorem 2.}\enskip{\it
The functions (\ref{e10}) are solution of the set of equations (\ref{e5})
if and only if
%
\begin{equation}\label{e14}
\begin{split}
n(n+1)\,H_{\theta,n}(r)-r\,E_{r,n}(r)=0, \quad
n(n+1)\,E_{\theta,n}(r)-r\,H_{r,n}(r)=0, \\
\frac{d}{dr}\bigl(rH_{\alpha,n}(r)\bigr)+k^2rE_{\theta,n}(r)-H_{r,n}(r)=0, \;\;
\frac{d}{dr}\bigl(rH_{\theta,n}(r)\bigr)-rE_{\alpha,n}(r)=0, \\
\frac{d}{dr}\bigl(rE_{\alpha,n}(r)\bigr)+k^2rH_{\theta,n}(r)-E_{r,n}(r)=0, \;\;
\frac{d}{dr}\bigl(rE_{\theta,n}(r)\bigr)-rH_{\alpha,n}(r)=0
\end{split}
\end{equation}
%
for $n=|m|,|m|+1,\dots$
}\vskip2mm
\emph{Proof}.
Two first equations in the set (\ref{e14}) follow from (\ref{e11}), (\ref{e12})
directly. The second and the third equalities of the set (\ref{e5}) are reduced
to
%\begin{multline*}
\sum_{n=|m|}^{+\infty}\biggl[\frac{d}{dr}\bigl(r\,H_{\alpha,n}(r)\bigr)
+k^2r\,E_{\theta,n}(r)-H_{r,n}(r)\biggr]\,\varphi_n(\theta) \\
-\frac{\omega\varepsilon_0\varepsilon}{m}\sum_{n=|m|}^{+\infty}
\biggl[\frac{d}{dr}\bigl(r\,H_{\theta,n}(r)\bigr)-r\,E_{\alpha,n}(r)\biggr]\,
\sin\theta\cdot\varphi'_n(\theta)=0,
\end{multline*}%%\begin{multline*}
-\frac1{m}\sum_{n=|m|}^{+\infty}\biggl[\frac{d}{dr}\bigl(r\,H_{\alpha,n}(r)\bigr)
+k^2r\,E_{\theta,n}(r)-H_{r,n}(r)\biggr]\,\varphi'_n(\theta) \\
+\omega\varepsilon_0\varepsilon\sum_{n=|m|}^{+\infty}
\biggl[\frac{d}{dr}\bigl(r\,H_{\theta,n}(r)\bigr)-r\,E_{\alpha,n}(r)\biggr]\,
\frac{\varphi_n(\theta)}{\sin\theta}=0.
\end{multline*}%
Let us multiply the second equality by $\sin\theta$ and use Lemma
(for $f(\theta)=0$, $g(\theta)=0$). Then we obtain another two
equations of the set (\ref{e14}).

The last two equations of this set can be obtained from 5th and 6th equalities
of the set (\ref{e5}).

\vskip2mm
The next statement follows from Theorem 2.

\vskip2mm
\textbf{Theorem 3.}\enskip{\it
The general solution of the set of equations (\ref{e5}) in the case $m\ne0$
has the form
$$
E_r(r,\theta)=\frac1{im}\sum_{n=|m|}^{+\infty}\frac{n(n+1)}{r}\,
\bigl[c_n\,\zeta^{(1)}_n(kr)+d_n\,\zeta^{(2)}_n(kr)\bigr]\,\varphi_n(\theta),
$$
\begin{multline*}
E_\theta(r,\theta)=-\frac{i\omega\mu_0\mu}{\sin\theta}\sum_{n=|m|}^{+\infty}
\bigl[a_n\,\zeta^{(1)}_n(kr)+b_n\,\zeta^{(2)}_n(kr)\bigr]\,\varphi_n(\theta) \\
+\frac1{im}\sum_{n=|m|}^{+\infty}
\bigl[c_n\,\frac1{r}\,\frac{d}{dr}\bigl(r\zeta^{(1)}_n(kr)\bigr)
+d_n\,\frac1{r}\,\frac{d}{dr}\bigl(r\zeta^{(2)}_n(kr)\bigr)\bigr]\,\varphi'_n(\theta),
\end{multline*}
\begin{multline}\label{e15}
E_\alpha(r,\theta)=\frac{\omega\mu_0\mu}{m}\sum_{n=|m|}^{+\infty}
\bigl[a_n\,\zeta^{(1)}_n(kr)+b_n\,\zeta^{(2)}_n(kr)\bigr]\,\varphi'_n(\theta) \\
+\frac1{\sin\theta}\sum_{n=|m|}^{+\infty}
\bigl[c_n\,\frac1{r}\,\frac{d}{dr}\bigl(r\zeta^{(1)}_n(kr)\bigr)
+d_n\,\frac1{r}\,\frac{d}{dr}\bigl(r\zeta^{(2)}_n(kr)\bigr)\bigr]\,\varphi_n(\theta),
\end{multline}
$$
H_r(r,\theta)=\frac1{im}\sum_{n=|m|}^{+\infty}\frac{n(n+1)}{r}\,
\bigl[a_n\,\zeta^{(1)}_n(kr)+b_n\,\zeta^{(2)}_n(kr)\bigr]\,\varphi_n(\theta),
$$
\begin{multline*}
H_\theta(r,\theta)=\frac1{im}\sum_{n=|m|}^{+\infty}
\bigl[a_n\,\frac1{r}\,\frac{d}{dr}\bigl(r\zeta^{(1)}_n(kr)\bigr)
+b_n\,\frac1{r}\,\frac{d}{dr}\bigl(r\zeta^{(2)}_n(kr)\bigr)\bigr]\,\varphi'_n(\theta) \\
+\frac{i\omega\varepsilon_0\varepsilon}{\sin\theta}\sum_{n=|m|}^{+\infty}
\bigl[c_n\,\zeta^{(1)}_n(kr)+d_n\,\zeta^{(2)}_n(kr)\bigr]\,\varphi_n(\theta),
\end{multline*}
\begin{multline*}
H_\alpha(r,\theta)=\frac1{\sin\theta}\sum_{n=|m|}^{+\infty}\,
\bigl[a_n\,\frac1{r}\,\frac{d}{dr}\bigl(r\zeta^{(1)}_n(kr)\bigr)
+b_n\,\frac1{r}\,\frac{d}{dr}\bigl(r\zeta^{(2)}_n(kr)\bigr)\bigr]\varphi_n(\theta) \\
-\frac{\omega\varepsilon_0\varepsilon}{m}\sum_{n=|m|}^{+\infty}\,
\bigl[c_n\,\zeta^{(1)}_n(kr)+d_n\,\zeta^{(2)}_n(kr)\bigr]\,\varphi'_n(\theta),
\end{multline*}
here
$
\zeta^{(j)}_n(z)=\displaystyle\sqrt{\frac{\pi}{2z}}\,H^{(j)}_{n+1/2}(z),\;\;j=1,2,
$
and $\;\;a_n,\;b_n,\;c_n,\;d_n$ are arbitrary constants.
}\vskip2mm \emph{Proof}. Firstly, it is necessary to construct the general
solution of the set of equations (\ref{e14}). The potential
functions $E_{\theta,n}$ and $H_{\theta,n}$ must satisfy the
equations of the form (\ref{e9}). Another unknown function can be
represented by potential functions.

After this step, we replace the coefficients of the series
(\ref{e10}) with their representations by the functions
$E_{\theta,n}$ and $H_{\theta,n}$. \enskip$\bullet$

Theorem 1 and Theorem 3 can be united.

\vskip2mm
\textbf{Theorem 4.}\enskip{\it
The general solution of the Maxwell set of equations in the spherical coordinates
has the form
%
\begin{equation}\label{e16}
\mathbf{E}(r,\theta,\alpha)=\sum_{m=-\infty}^{+\infty}\mathbf{E}_m(r,\theta)e^{im\alpha},
\;\;
\mathbf{H}(r,\theta,\alpha)=\sum_{m=-\infty}^{+\infty}\mathbf{H}_m(r,\theta)e^{im\alpha},
\end{equation}
%
where components of vector-functions
$\;\mathbf{E}_m=(E_{m,r},\,E_{m,\theta},\,E_{m,\alpha})\;$
and \\
$\mathbf{H}_m=(H_{m,r},\,H_{m,\theta},\,H_{m,\alpha})\;$ are defined
by formulas (\ref{e8}) in the case of $m=0$ and by formulas
(\ref{e15}) in the case of $m\ne0$. }\vskip2mm
\textbf{Remark 1.}\enskip
If we introduce the potentials of electrical field and of magnetic field
$
\displaystyle
u(r,\theta)=\sum_{n=|m|}^{+\infty}E_{\theta,n}(r)\,\varphi_n(\theta),\qquad
v(r,\theta)=\sum_{n=|m|}^{+\infty}H_{\theta,n}(r)\,\varphi_n(\theta),
$
then it is easy to show, that the solution of the Maxwell set of equations
in the spherical coordinates has also the form
$$
E_r=\frac1{im}\,\bigl(\frac{\partial^2(rv)}{\partial
r^2}+k^2r\,v\bigr),\qquad
H_r=\frac1{im}\,\bigl(\frac{\partial^2(ru)}{\partial
r^2}+k^2r\,u\bigr),
$$$$
E_\theta=-\frac{i\omega\mu_0\mu}{\sin\theta}\,u+\frac1{imr}\,\frac{\partial^2(rv)}{\partial\theta\,\partial
r},\qquad
H_\theta=\frac1{imr}\,\frac{\partial^2(ru)}{\partial\theta\,\partial
r}+\frac{i\omega\varepsilon_0\varepsilon}{\sin\theta}\,v,
$$$$
E_\alpha=\frac{i\omega\mu_0\mu}{im}\,\frac{\partial
u}{\partial\theta}+\frac1{r\sin\theta}\,\frac{\partial(rv)}{\partial
r},\qquad H_\alpha=\frac1{r\sin\theta}\,\frac{\partial(ru)}{\partial
r}-\frac{i\omega\varepsilon_0\varepsilon}{im}\,\frac{\partial
v}{\partial\theta},
$$
where the functions $u$ and $v$ satisfy the equation
\begin{equation}\label{e17}
r\,\frac{\partial^2(r\,u)}{\partial r^2}
+\frac1{\sin\theta}\,\frac{\partial}{\partial\theta}\bigl(\sin\theta\cdot\frac{\partial
u}{\partial\theta}\bigr)
+\bigl(k^2r^2-\frac{m^2}{\sin^2\theta}\bigr)\,u=0.
\end{equation}

The solution of the Maxwell set %of equations
can be determined unique\-ly
if traces of tangential components of vectors $\mathbf{E}$ and $\mathbf{H}$ are
given on the sphere.

The solution of the Maxwell set of equations is called positively oriented if
representation (\ref{e16}) consists of summands with Hankel functions of the second kind only
($a_n=0,\;c_n=0$ for all $n$), or solution is called negatively oriented if
representation (\ref{e16}) consists of summands with Hankel functions of the first kind only
($b_n=0,\;d_n=0$ for all $n$). The sum of two oppositely oriented solutions is
non-oriented solution.

If we calculate the Pointing vector for solutions of the Maxwell set, then
we obtain that positively oriented solutions transfer energy of the electromagnetic
field along the $r$-axis, and negatively oriented solutions transfer energy
along another direction. It can be shown that the energy flow of oriented solution
is the sum of energy flows of separate summands.

\vskip2mm
The boundary value problems for the Maxwell set of equations in coordinate domains
break down into infinite sets of boundary value problems for the set of equations
(\ref{e5}). Therefore we consider in detail different variants of these problems only.

The tangential components of vectors $\mathbf{E}$ and $\mathbf{H}$ in the case
of positively oriented solutions have the form

%\begin{equation}\label{e18}
\begin{split}
E_\theta(r,\theta)=\sum_{n=1}^{+\infty}
d_n\,\frac1{r}\,\frac{d}{dr}\bigl(r\zeta^{(2)}_n(kr)\bigr)\,\varphi'_n(\theta),\quad
E_\alpha(r,\theta)=i\omega\mu_0\mu\sum_{n=1}^{+\infty}
b_n\,\zeta^{(2)}_n(kr)\,\varphi'_n(\theta), \\
H_\theta(r,\theta)=\sum_{n=1}^{+\infty}
b_n\,\frac1{r}\,\frac{d}{dr}\bigl(r\zeta^{(2)}_n(kr)\bigr)\,\varphi'_n(\theta),\quad
H_\alpha(r,\theta)=-i\omega\varepsilon_0\varepsilon\sum_{n=1}^{+\infty}\,
d_n\,\zeta^{(2)}_n(kr)\,\varphi'_n(\theta).
\end{split}
\end{equation}%
It is easy to show that the coefficients $b_n$ and $d_n$ are determined uniquely
from the conditions
%\begin{equation}\label{e19}
E_\theta(R,\theta)=e_\theta(\theta),\qquad
E_\alpha(R,\theta)=e_\alpha(\theta)\qquad\mbox{or}
\end{equation}%%\begin{equation}\label{e20}
H_\theta(R,\theta)=h_\theta(\theta),\qquad
H_\alpha(R,\theta)=h_\alpha(\theta).
\end{equation}%
Obviously, if $e_{\theta,n}$ and $e_{\alpha,n}$ are the coefficients
of expansions by the basis set $\varphi'_n(\theta)$ of boundary
functions from the conditions (\ref{e19}), then it is necessary to
solve following simplest equations:
$$
d_n\,\frac1{R}\,\frac{d}{dr}\bigl(r\zeta^{(2)}_n(kr)\bigr)\bigr|_{r=R}=e_{\theta,n},\quad
i\omega\mu_0\,b_n\,\zeta^{(2)}_n(kR)=e_{\alpha,n},\quad n=1,2,\dots,
$$
the coefficients in front of unknown numbers are not equal to zero.

If $m\ne0$ then tangential components $E_\theta(r,\theta)$, $\;E_\alpha(r,\theta)$,
$\;H_\theta(r,\theta)$, $\;H_\alpha(r,\theta)$
of the positively oriented solution are
$$
-\frac{i\omega\mu_0\mu}{\sin\theta}\sum_{n=|m|}^{+\infty}
b_n\,\zeta^{(2)}_n(kr)\,\varphi_n(\theta)
+\frac1{im}\sum_{n=|m|}^{+\infty}
d_n\,\frac1{r}\,\frac{d}{dr}\bigl(r\zeta^{(2)}_n(kr)\bigr)\,\varphi'_n(\theta),
$$$$
\frac{\omega\mu_0\mu}{m}\sum_{n=|m|}^{+\infty}
b_n\,\zeta^{(2)}_n(kr)\,\varphi'_n(\theta) \\
+\frac1{\sin\theta}\sum_{n=|m|}^{+\infty}
d_n\,\frac1{r}\,\frac{d}{dr}\bigl(r\zeta^{(2)}_n(kr)\bigr)\,\varphi_n(\theta),
$$\begin{equation}\label{e21}
\frac1{im}\sum_{n=|m|}^{+\infty}
b_n\,\frac1{r}\,\frac{d}{dr}\bigl(r\zeta^{(2)}_n(kr)\bigr)\,\varphi'_n(\theta)
+\frac{i\omega\varepsilon_0\varepsilon}{\sin\theta}\sum_{n=|m|}^{+\infty}
d_n\,\zeta^{(2)}_n(kr)\,\varphi_n(\theta),
\end{equation}$$
\frac1{\sin\theta}\sum_{n=|m|}^{+\infty}\,
b_n\,\frac1{r}\,\frac{d}{dr}\bigl(r\zeta^{(2)}_n(kr)\bigr)\,\varphi_n(\theta) \\
-\frac{\omega\varepsilon_0\varepsilon}{m}\sum_{n=|m|}^{+\infty}\,
d_n\,\zeta^{(2)}_n(kr)\,\varphi'_n(\theta).
$$
In this case the conditions (\ref{e19}) give the pair of summatorial equations
%\begin{equation}\label{e22}
\begin{split}
-\frac{i\omega\mu_0\mu}{\sin\theta}\sum_{n=|m|}^{+\infty}
b_n\,\zeta^{(2)}_n(kR)\,\varphi_n(\theta)
+\frac1{im}\sum_{n=|m|}^{+\infty}
d_n\,\{\zeta^{(2)}_n\}(k,R)\,\varphi'_n(\theta)
=e_\theta(\theta), \\
\frac{\omega\mu_0\mu}{m}\sum_{n=|m|}^{+\infty}
b_n\,\zeta^{(2)}_n(kR)\,\varphi'_n(\theta)
+\frac1{\sin\theta}\sum_{n=|m|}^{+\infty}
d_n\,\{\zeta^{(2)}_n\}(k,R)\,\varphi_n(\theta) =e_\alpha(\theta),
\end{split}
\end{equation}%
where
$
\{\zeta^{(j)}_n\}(k,R)=\frac1{R}\,\frac{d}{dr}\bigl(r\zeta^{(j)}_n(kr)\bigr)\Bigr|_{r=R},
\quad j=1,2.
$\vskip2mm
\textbf{Theorem 5.}\enskip{\it
The exterior boundary value problem for the set of equations (\ref{e5})
with boundary conditions (\ref{e19}) or (\ref{e20}) has the unique positively oriented solution
for any boundary functions.
}\vskip2mm
Proof.
The case of $m=0$ was considered previously. If $m\ne0$ then it follows
from formulas (\ref{e17}) that the unique solution of the equations (\ref{e22}) is
%\begin{equation}\label{e23}
-i\omega\mu_0\mu b_k\zeta^{(2)}_k(kR)=F_{k,m} \int\limits_0^{\pi}\Bigl[

for $k=|m|,|m|+1,\dots$
If the conditions (\ref{e20}) are given, then we have

-\frac{\omega\varepsilon_0\varepsilon}{m}\sum_{n=|m|}^{+\infty}

$$

\int\limits_0^{\pi}\Bigl[ m^2\,h_\theta(\theta)+im\,(\sin\theta\cdot

b_k\,\{\zeta^{(2)}_k\}(k,R)=F_{k,m} \int\limits_0^{\pi}\Bigl[

\end{equation}%
for $k=|m|,|m|+1,\dots$ and
$
b_n\,\{\zeta^{(2)}_n\}(k,R)=h_{\theta,n},\quad
-i\omega\varepsilon_0\varepsilon\,d_n\,\zeta^{(2)}_n(kR)=h_{\alpha,n},\quad
n=1,2,\dots
$
for $m=0$.\enskip$\bullet$\vskip2mm
If solution of the Maxwell set of equations contains Hankel functions,
then it has singularities in the point $r=0$.
It is possible to find this solution in the whole space without the point $r=0$(and without infinity point) in the class of positively oriented solutions
satisfying conditions (\ref{e19}) or (\ref{e20}).
Analogous statements remain for negatively oriented solutions (this class
is used in the case when inverse problems are considered).
Furthermore, the oriented solution of the Maxwell set are determined uniquely
by the conditions (\ref{e19}) or (\ref{e20}) if the singularities in the point $r=0$
are permissible.

If the sources of electromagnetic field are absent in the interior of the sphere,
then it is necessary to change class of solutions.
The coefficients before Hankel functions of different kind must be the same value
because if one oriented summand brings the energy on the sphere then the second
oriented summand takes off this energy backwards. In this case only Bessel
functions are used in the general solution and in every particular solution.
We call these solutions as bounded solutions in the center of the sphere.
The tangential components
$E_\theta(r,\theta)$, $\;E_\alpha(r,\theta)$,
$\;H_\theta(r,\theta)$, $\;H_\alpha(r,\theta)$
of bounded in the center of the sphere
vectors $\mathbf{E}$ and $\mathbf{H}$ have the form
%\begin{equation}\label{e27}
\begin{split}
\sum_{n=1}^{+\infty}
c_n\,\frac1{r}\,\frac{d}{dr}\bigl(rj_n(kr)\bigr)\,\varphi'_n(\theta), \quad
i\omega\mu_0\mu\sum_{n=1}^{+\infty}
a_n\,j_n(kr)\,\varphi'_n(\theta), \\
\sum_{n=1}^{+\infty}
a_n\,\frac1{r}\,\frac{d}{dr}\bigl(rj_n(kr)\bigr)\,\varphi'_n(\theta), \quad

c_n\,j_n(kr)\,\varphi'_n(\theta)

\end{equation}%\begin{equation}\label{e28}
\begin{split}
-\frac{i\omega\mu_0\mu}{\sin\theta}\sum_{n=|m|}^{+\infty}

+\frac1{im}\sum_{n=|m|}^{+\infty}
c_n\,\frac1{r}\,\frac{d}{dr}\bigl(rj_n(kr)\bigr)\,\varphi'_n(\theta),\\
\frac{\omega\mu_0\mu}{m}\sum_{n=|m|}^{+\infty}
a_n\,j_n(kr)\,\varphi'_n(\theta)
+\frac1{\sin\theta}\sum_{n=|m|}^{+\infty}
c_n\,\frac1{r}\,\frac{d}{dr}\bigl(rj_n(kr)\bigr)\,\varphi_n(\theta),\\
\frac1{im}\sum_{n=|m|}^{+\infty}

+\frac{i\omega\varepsilon_0\varepsilon}{\sin\theta}\sum_{n=|m|}^{+\infty}
c_n\,j_n(kr)\,\varphi_n(\theta),\\
\frac1{\sin\theta}\sum_{n=|m|}^{+\infty}\,
a_n\,\frac1{r}\,\frac{d}{dr}\bigl(rj_n(kr)\bigr)\,\varphi_n(\theta)
-\frac{\omega\varepsilon_0\varepsilon}{m}\sum_{n=|m|}^{+\infty}\,
c_n\,j_n(kr)\,\varphi'_n(\theta)
\end{split}
\end{equation}%
in the case $m=0$ and in the case $m\ne0$ respectively.

We find the solution of interior boundary value problem for the set of equations
(\ref{e5}) with boundary conditions (\ref{e19}) in the form (\ref{e27}), (\ref{e28}).
The coefficients of expansion of solution by spherical functions
satisfy the following sets of equations:
$
c_n\,\{j_n\}(k,R)=e_{\theta,n},\qquad
i\omega\mu_0\mu\,a_n\,j_n(kR)=e_{\alpha,n}
$
in the case $m=0$, and
$$
-\frac{i\omega\mu_0\mu}{\sin\theta}\sum_{n=|m|}^{+\infty}
a_n\,j_n(kR)\,\varphi_n(\theta) +\frac1{im}\sum_{n=|m|}^{+\infty}
c_n\,\{j_n\}(k,R)\,\varphi'_n(\theta) =e_\theta(\theta),
$$$$
\frac{\omega\mu_0\mu}{m}\sum_{n=|m|}^{+\infty}
a_n\,j_n(kR)\,\varphi'_n(\theta)
+\frac1{\sin\theta}\sum_{n=|m|}^{+\infty}
c_n\,\{j_n\}(k,R)\,\varphi_n(\theta) =e_\alpha(\theta)
$$
in the case $m\ne0$.

In contrast to all previous problems
the factors before unknown coefficients can be equal to zero
(resonance case). In this case the homogeneous boundary value problem
has non-trivial solutions, and the heterogeneous problem has the unique solution
but if and only if boundary functions satisfy solvability conditions.

The resonance case arises when
%\begin{equation}\label{e29}
j_n(kR)=0\qquad\mbox{or}\qquad\{j_n\}(k,R)
=\frac1{R}\,\frac{d}{dr}\Bigl(r\,j_n(kr)\Bigr)\Bigr|_{r=R}=0.
\end{equation}%
The interior boundary value problem with condition (\ref{e20}) can be investigated
analogously.

\vskip2mm
\textbf{Theorem 6.}\enskip{\it
If condition (\ref{e29}) is fulfilled then non-trivial solutions of the homogeneous
boundary value problem describe eigen waves of a spherical resonator, these waves
propagate without losses in the medium without sources.

If condition (\ref{e29}) is not fulfilled then interior boundary value problem with condition
(\ref{e19}) or (\ref{e20}) has the unique solution bounded in the center of the sphere.
}

We will show that the existence of non-trivial solutions of interior boundary value
problem does not influence on the uniquely solvability of the diffraction problem of the
electromagnetic wave on the sphere.

Let an electromagnetic wave falls down on the dielectric sphere.
It is necessary to find electromagnetic field arising by diffraction of this wave:
negatively oriented wave inside sphere and positively oriented wave outside sphere.

We denote the dielectric indexes and wave numbers inside sphere and
outside sphere: $\varepsilon_+,\,k_+$ and $\varepsilon_-,\,k_-$
respectively. The magnetic indexes are equal.

Let tangential components of vectors $\mathbf{E}$ and $\mathbf{H}$ of the initial wave be

in the case $m=0$ and
%\begin{multline*}
-\frac{i\omega\mu_0\mu}{\sin\theta}\sum_{n=|m|}^{+\infty}

\textbf{Remark 2.}\enskip
If the initial wave is a plane wave then its expansions by spherical harmonics contain
the summands for $m=-1$ and $m=1$ only.

It was shown that oriented solution of the set of equations (\ref{e5})
can be found by only one of conditions (\ref{e19}) or (\ref{e20}). If both these
condition are given then non-oriented solution can be constructed.

We will seek the positively oriented solution of the set (\ref{e5})
outside sphere in the case when both boundary conditions are fulfilled.
This problem is over-determined. Boundary functions can not be given
arbitrary. We will find a connection between these functions in the boundary
conditions of exterior over-determined problem.

The coefficients $b_k$ and $d_k$ in the positively oriented general solution

\vskip2mm \textbf{Theorem 8.}\enskip{\it Functions
$e_\theta(\theta),\;e_\alpha(\theta),\;h_\theta(\theta),\;h_\alpha(\theta)$
are traces on the sphere of positively oriented solution of Maxwell
set of equations for $r>R$ if and only if their Fourier coefficients
fulfil the equations (\ref{e33}), (\ref{e34}), or (\ref{e35}),
(\ref{e36}), or (\ref{e37}), (\ref{e38}), or (\ref{e39}),
(\ref{e40}.) }
